question: Question_01_(n)
statement: Use the linear approximation to ln(x) at x=1 to estimate ln(0.8).
sols:
We use the linear approximation of $\ln(x)$ at $x=1$ to estimate
$\ln(0.8)$. (Approximating at \emph{x = 1} is a logical choice, as 1 is
close to 0.8, and we know that $\ln(1) = 0$.)

We know $\frac{d}{dx}\ln(x)=\frac1x$, which is equal to 1 when $x=1$.
Substituting this into the linear approximation formula, we get,

\[\ln(0.8)\approx \ln(1)+1(0.8-1) = 0-0.2=-0.2\]
hints:
The graph of the linear approximation taken at $a=1$ is the tangent line
to the curve at $a=1$.

The linear approximation to a function $f$ at $x=a$ is

\[L(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a).\]
